entry.title: Incompleteness theorems
entry.content:
Everyone has a favourite literature author, music composer, philosopher or scientist. In this post I am going to tell about my favourite matematician: Kurt Gödel and about his famous incompleteness theorems.

Kurt Gödel was ill and mentally unstable. He had a paranoid fear that someone would poison him. He trusted only his wife, and would eat the food she prepared for him or alternatively, she would taste any provided food before he ate it. When she became ill in 1977 and had to be hospitalized for six months, Gödel refused to eat, and eventually died of malnutrition in 1978 at the age of 71 [2]. When he died, he weighed only 30kg.

So back to incompleteness theorems. But before let me explain you the concepts like “formal system”, “consistency”, and “completeness”. Formal system is a system of axioms equipped with rules of inference, which allow one to generate new theorems. A formal system is complete if for every statement of the language of the system, either the statement or its negation can be derived (i.e., proved) in the system. A formal system is consistent if there is no statement such that the statement itself and its negation are both proofable in the system.
entry.summary: Everyone has a favourite literature author, music composer, philosopher or scientist. In this post I am going to tell about my favourite matematician: Kurt Gödel and about his famous incompleteness theorems.

entry.title: Task Item List
entry.content:
This post tests the style of a task item list.

Source:

- [x] Eating
- [ ] Walking
  - [ ] Running
- [ ] Sleeping

Rendered:

  • Eating
  • Walking
    • Running
  • Sleeping
entry.summary: This post tests the style of a task item list.
